headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: Maui County Files Lawsuit Against Utility Companies; WAPO: Lawyers Say Maui Utility May Have Compromised Evidence In Wildfire Probe; New Footage Shows Terrifying Ordeal Inside Cable Car 900 Feet In The Air. Aired 10:30-11a ET

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.sentences: So, they're saying no such thing was going on. The challenge will be, as plaintiffs and what's going to be nine lawsuits which will turn into more accountability, which is, did that substation, these transformers, damaged by winds and hurricanes and other things, were they not properly maintained? Were they sparking? Did they start this fire, which then started other fires, which then tells the terrible story of what's occurred and the terrible loss? And will ATF investigators be able to reconstruct that?

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I'm curious about the ATF investigators that are on the ground. Usually, the U.S. Forest Service is responsible for some of this. But, now the ATF is there. Why?

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.sentences: Well, ATF holds the ticket among federal investigative agencies on arson, not just explosives, and they have excellent arson investigators and a first rate lab, probably when it comes to arson, the best in the country, but limited experience in forest fires --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.sentences: -- because the Forest Service usually does it because it's usually on national parks and national forest lands. In this case, this isn't federal lands. So, ATF has the ticket. What they're going to have to do here is go to where this material has been removed, where it's cataloged and so on. Look at whatever photographic, whether it's satellite or other imagery, there was before to say, OK --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It correlates.

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.sentences: -- what did this look like before? Where did these things go? And then, look at their normal point of origin science in terms of where do we think this started, and where do we think it moved. And their job will be harder, but they're very good at it.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I did not realize that they had this huge arson investigation, because I always think about them as --

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.sentences: Guns and bombs.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: -- your guns and bombs. Right.

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Exactly. John Miller, it's always a pleasure. I always learn something when you're here. So, you can come back every day. I know --

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Sara.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: -- that's -- it's a bit much. It's a big ask. But --

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.sentences: Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: On Monday, the nation will commemorate 60 years since the historic march on Washington. On August 28, 1963, hundreds of thousands marched through the streets of the nation's capital to fight for Jobs and Freedom. It was the day of Martin Luther King's historic 'I Have a Dream' speech. The march proved critical in helping push for the passage of new laws, including the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which outlawed overt racial discrimination. CNN's Jason Carroll sat down with two activists who were at that historic march, and they say the fight for equality is still not over.(VIDEO PLAYING)

utterances.speaker: JASON CARROLL, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: It was a call for economic and racial equality, a call to action that brought more than 200,000 people to the National Mall in Washington, D.C. on August 28, 60 years ago, a day best remembered for Martin Luther King Jr. 's historic 'I Have a Dream' speech.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) MARTIN LUTHER KING JR., AMERICAN MINSTER: Now is the time to make real the promises of democracy. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: Among the hundreds of thousands, two young activists who were filled with hope.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COURTLAND COX, CHAIRMAN, SNCC LEGACY PROJECT
utterances.sentences: I was all the way on the top.

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: All the way on the top -- COX

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: -- over to the left.

utterances.speaker: COX
utterances.sentences: Yes. Over to the left.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: Courtland Cox is now 82. But, 60 years ago, he was a 22-year- old, working for the civil rights organization SNCC, the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COX
utterances.sentences: And what I remember is the platform is there in the mid center.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: Edward Flanagan was there too.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: Where were you? Do you remember?EDWARD FLANAGAN, ATTENDED 1963 MARCH ON WASHINGTON: I was sitting on the wall up, top there, by the entertainers. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: Flanagan is 80 now, but on the day of the march, he was a 20- year-old who had just finished his shift as a waiter. Like scores of others, he wanted to take a stand for civil rights.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: FLANAGAN
utterances.sentences: I was very close to Joan Baez. OK? I was able to notice he was barefoot. And I have a new pair to change.

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: She was barefoot.

utterances.speaker: FLANAGAN
utterances.sentences: She was barefoot.(VIDEO PLAYING) (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: A march six decades ago, now seen through the eyes of two different men who shared the same goal many did that day.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COX
utterances.sentences: I thought it was a day is that we succeeded in changing this country.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: As a young organizer, Cox was responsible for arranging safe transportation for people making the trek from the south to Washington, D.C. He says there were challenges from top to bottom, much had to be done in very little time.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COX
utterances.sentences: The challenge from the bottom was the logistics of getting people here. Over a period, I'm trying to get trailways, buses. I'm trying to get Greyhound buses, and the drivers are saying, look, it's dangerous bringing people to the south. The challenge from the top was the Kennedy administration was opposed to John Lewis's speech.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: Cox worked alongside then 23-year-old civil rights activist John Lewis, who was the Chairman of SNCC. This picture shows the two men as they rewrote the speech to tone it down, to make it less critical of the Kennedy administration's civil rights bill, which they felt didn't go far enough to protect people from police brutality.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COX
utterances.sentences: John Lewis, Jim Forman and myself, were in the back of the Lincoln Memorial, re-changing John Lewis's speech to make sure that while it was critical, it was not negative.

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: That had to have been an incredible moment.

utterances.speaker: COX
utterances.sentences: Well, yes, but what was more incredible to me is that John got up after all of that controversy and delivered a fantastic speech.

utterances.speaker: JOHN LEWIS, CIVIL RIGHTS ACTIVIST
utterances.sentences: It is true that we support the administration's civil rights bill. We support it with great reservation, however.(CROSSTALK) (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: This week, Flanagan brought his daughters back to the place history was made. He'll be back again Saturday.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: FLANAGAN
utterances.sentences: That's the fact (ph) where the entertainers were.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: Cox prefers to stay away this time, saying his marching days are behind him. Both agree, while much was accomplished that day, the work is not over.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: FLANAGAN
utterances.sentences: We are still well in a much better place than we were in 1963, not in the place where one would expect 60 years on.

utterances.speaker: COX
utterances.sentences: We succeeded in doing a number of things by what we did in the past, but we also know that we have to do much more for the future.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: And both Mr. Cox and Mr. Flanagan also expressed grave concern as well as civil rights leaders doing the same that there is an ongoing effort in this day and age to try to turn the clock back. That is why they are so concerned about where we are now. Big concern is that what's happening is people are trying to erase African American history.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Jason, I got to say, just sit with those people who touched history or were there, to see the picture revising John Lewis's speech.

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: And their memory, crystal clear.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: But, how could you forget, what an important day and a wonderful piece. Thanks so much, Jason.

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Nearly everywhere you go, it seems like you're being asked to leave a tip, whether it's at a coffee shop, at a taxi or at a salon. This is leading to confusion these days at the checkout about whether a tip is required, and if so, how much, because for some workers, it is essential, but there is a lot of debate it has sparked around all of it. CNN's Vanessa Yurkevich has the details.

utterances.speaker: VANESSA YURKEVICH, CNN BUSINESS AND POLITICS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: This scream is stressful for many.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Does the flip of the screen feel like a lot of pressure?

utterances.speaker: CARLY CULLEN, NEW YORK RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: It does, and they give you options like 10, 15, 20, even with like Uber, Dash --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CULLEN
utterances.sentences: -- and like Grubhub, all of it, like everything is, tip, tip, tip.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Do you think that tipping has gotten out of control?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Tips are part of American culture, meant to be a thank you for good service. But, today, more and more Americans are confronted with the question, would you like to add a tip?(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CULLEN
utterances.sentences: It is tricky everywhere, right? Like, if you're at a coffee shop, if you're at the hairstylist, if you're coming out of a taxi, like I don't know the rules then and I often don't know what to tip.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: A recent study found that, in a high number of cases, participants who were presented with a tip screen had more negative emotions to the payment experience than those that didn't. And it wasn't even a real world scenario.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DYLAN BOSCH, NEW YORK RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: Let's say you go to a coffee shop and all they do just twist around the laptop. It was like, why am I tipping?(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: But, the small group we spoke to said more often than not they do end up tipping.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JOSEPH GUZMEN, NEW YORK RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: I put the dollar too, I don't mind it as long as like, you know, it's not a lie. I just put it because I don't mind this is -- actually, I am helping out other people.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: This is provisions on state, a butcher shop. There is no table service, no cooking or serving. Yet, they will ask you if you'd like to tip.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: A flip screen in a butcher shop --

utterances.speaker: EMILY MINGRONE, CONNECTICUT RESTAURANT OWNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: -- I don't think I've ever seen that before.

utterances.speaker: MINGRONE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: How did you decide to do that?

utterances.speaker: MINGRONE
utterances.sentences: These men and women have a knowledge base that they're sharing and taking care to share with the guests that come through the door, and they're not pressured to tip, but they want to because they're paying for a service provided.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Emily Mingrone owns the butcher shop and two restaurants in New Haven, Connecticut. At the restaurants, her front of house staff make the state's tipped minimum wage, $6.38 an hour. Tips bring them to $40 an hour on average. But, the back of house staff make half that and aren't eligible for tips.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: This movement to get rid of the tipped minimum wage, are you for it, against it?

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Eight states have abolished the tipped minimum wage, which in some is as low as $2.13 an hour. The National Restaurant Association is fighting against it, calling it a top issue.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MINGRONE
utterances.sentences: That's money that's going to come out of my pocket, take away from the people that aren't getting tipped, I would need to raise my prices, which then causes pushback from the guest.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: But, the group One Fair Wage is moving legislation and ballot measures to end the tip to minimum wage in 25 other states, including Illinois.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DESTINY FOX, CHICAGO SERVER
utterances.sentences: That's how I live, is with tips.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Destiny Fox works in two Chicago restaurants. She is saving up for school. She makes just above the state's tipped minimum wage, taking home $9.40 an hour, tips at 80 percent to her take home pay. Without it --(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: FOX
utterances.sentences: It wouldn't give me the means to live, to pay my bills, to eat, and to do the things that I'm planning on doing, school. And I mean, it's everything.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Listen, this is a complicated issue. But, the consensus is, if you receive good service at a restaurant or someone makes your day at a coffee shop, you tip 20 percent at the restaurant, $1 or $2 at the coffee shop. One thing to know, when they flipped that screen on you, the person who is serving you actually doesn't know if you tip or not, and they don't know how much.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, interesting. I think that is part of --

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Take some of the pressure off, right?

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. But, it is -- it's -- I think it's also important to see the faces behind that screen that turns in your face, and to see the people behind the tip, if you will.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's based on service. How well do you think that person served you? That's what your tip should be.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Thanks for doing that.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: It's good to see you, Vanessa. Sara.
